title: Psychophysiology 1: Introduction
topic: History, scope, and mind-body foundations of psychophysiology.

questions.question: What does the mind-body problem mainly address?

options.text: How sleep changes memory performance.
How conscious experiences relate to the physical body.
How the spinal cord controls reflexes.
How to place EEG electrodes.

questions.explanation: The mind-body problem concerns the relationship between mental and physical phenomena.

questions.question: Which statement best reflects a monist position?

options.text: Mind and body are fully separate substances.
Only behavior can be studied scientifically.
Mental and physical events are aspects of one underlying reality.
Physiology and psychology cannot be integrated.

questions.explanation: Monism proposes one underlying basis for both mind and body.

questions.question: In psychophysiology, a common design is:

options.text: physiological IV and behavioral DV.
behavioral IV and physiological DV.
physiological IV and physiological DV only.
clinical diagnosis as the only IV.

questions.explanation: A standard formulation uses behavioral manipulation and physiological dependent measures.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Dualism?

options.text: Mind and body are treated as separate entities.
Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.
Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.
Emotion and physiological response arise in parallel.

questions.explanation: Mind and body are treated as separate entities.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Monism?

options.text: Mind and body are treated as separate entities.
Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.
Emotion and physiological response arise in parallel.
Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.

questions.explanation: Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.

questions.question: Which statement best describes James-Lange theory?

options.text: Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.
Emotion and physiological response arise in parallel.
Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.
Mind and body are treated as separate entities.

questions.explanation: Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Cannon-Bard theory?

options.text: Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.
Emotion and physiological response arise in parallel.
Mind and body are treated as separate entities.
Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.

questions.explanation: Emotion and physiological response arise in parallel.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Psychophysiology scope?

options.text: It studies links between psychological and physiological events.
Mind and body are treated as separate entities.
Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.
Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.

questions.explanation: It studies links between psychological and physiological events.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Measurement rationale?

options.text: Mind and body are treated as separate entities.
Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.
Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.
Physiological signals can reveal covert processes.

questions.explanation: Physiological signals can reveal covert processes.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Causal inference?

options.text: Mental and physical events are aspects of one reality.
Emotion is interpreted from bodily responses.
Strong causal claims require controlled manipulation.
Mind and body are treated as separate entities.

questions.explanation: Strong causal claims require controlled manipulation.

title: Psychophysiology 2.1: Nervous System
topic: Structural and functional organization of the human nervous system.

questions.question: Which structures form the central nervous system (CNS)?

options.text: Brain and peripheral nerves.
Cranial nerves and spinal nerves.
Brain and spinal cord.
Somatic and autonomic divisions.

questions.explanation: The CNS is defined as the brain plus spinal cord.

questions.question: The peripheral nervous system (PNS) includes:

options.text: Only neurons in the cortex.
Only neurons in the spinal cord.
Neural structures outside brain and spinal cord.
Only sympathetic neurons.

questions.explanation: The PNS covers neural structures outside CNS boundaries.

questions.question: Which pairing is correct?

options.text: Sympathetic: rest-digest; Parasympathetic: fight-flight.
Sympathetic: fight-flight; Parasympathetic: rest-digest.
Both are purely voluntary systems.
Both only control skeletal muscle.

questions.explanation: Sympathetic and parasympathetic branches have opposite dominant functions.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Central nervous system?

options.text: The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.
The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.
It supports voluntary striated muscle control.
It regulates involuntary organs, glands, and cardiac/smooth muscle.

questions.explanation: The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Peripheral nervous system?

options.text: The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.
It supports voluntary striated muscle control.
It regulates involuntary organs, glands, and cardiac/smooth muscle.
The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.

questions.explanation: The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Somatic nervous system?

options.text: The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.
It regulates involuntary organs, glands, and cardiac/smooth muscle.
It supports voluntary striated muscle control.
The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.

questions.explanation: It supports voluntary striated muscle control.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Autonomic nervous system?

options.text: It supports voluntary striated muscle control.
It regulates involuntary organs, glands, and cardiac/smooth muscle.
The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.
The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.

questions.explanation: It regulates involuntary organs, glands, and cardiac/smooth muscle.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Sympathetic branch?

options.text: It is typically dominant in fight-or-flight contexts.
The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.
The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.
It supports voluntary striated muscle control.

questions.explanation: It is typically dominant in fight-or-flight contexts.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Parasympathetic branch?

options.text: The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.
The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.
It supports voluntary striated muscle control.
It is typically dominant in rest-and-digest states.

questions.explanation: It is typically dominant in rest-and-digest states.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Endocrine communication?

options.text: The PNS includes neural structures outside CNS.
It supports voluntary striated muscle control.
It uses hormones and is slower than neural signaling.
The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord.

questions.explanation: It uses hormones and is slower than neural signaling.

title: Psychophysiology 2.2: Neurons
topic: Neuron types, membrane dynamics, and neuronal signaling principles.

questions.question: Which neuron type is activated by stimuli and relays information onward?

options.text: Sensory (afferent) neuron.
Motor (efferent) neuron.
Glial support cell.
Pacemaker cell.

questions.explanation: Sensory neurons are activated by stimuli and transmit signals to other neurons.

questions.question: What maintains the resting membrane potential near -70 mV?

options.text: Calcium-magnesium pump.
Sodium-potassium pump.
Myelin insulation only.
Neurotransmitter release.

questions.explanation: The Na+/K+ pump supports ionic gradients that sustain resting potential.

questions.question: Why do myelinated axons often conduct faster?

options.text: They produce higher voltage spikes.
They have larger somas.
They use saltatory conduction between nodes.
They no longer require ion channels.

questions.explanation: Myelin enables saltatory propagation, increasing conduction velocity.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Sensory neurons?

options.text: They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.
They integrate and relay signals between neurons.
They transmit neural output to effector organs.
Typical neuronal resting potential is around -70 mV.

questions.explanation: They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Interneurons?

options.text: They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.
They transmit neural output to effector organs.
Typical neuronal resting potential is around -70 mV.
They integrate and relay signals between neurons.

questions.explanation: They integrate and relay signals between neurons.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Motor neurons?

options.text: They integrate and relay signals between neurons.
Typical neuronal resting potential is around -70 mV.
They transmit neural output to effector organs.
They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.

questions.explanation: They transmit neural output to effector organs.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Resting potential?

options.text: They transmit neural output to effector organs.
Typical neuronal resting potential is around -70 mV.
They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.
They integrate and relay signals between neurons.

questions.explanation: Typical neuronal resting potential is around -70 mV.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Na+/K+ pump?

options.text: It transports sodium out and potassium in.
They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.
They integrate and relay signals between neurons.
They transmit neural output to effector organs.

questions.explanation: It transports sodium out and potassium in.

questions.question: Which statement best describes EPSP?

options.text: They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.
They integrate and relay signals between neurons.
They transmit neural output to effector organs.
It increases the likelihood of action potential firing.

questions.explanation: It increases the likelihood of action potential firing.

questions.question: Which statement best describes IPSP?

options.text: They integrate and relay signals between neurons.
They transmit neural output to effector organs.
It decreases the likelihood of action potential firing.
They detect stimulation and relay activity onward.

questions.explanation: It decreases the likelihood of action potential firing.

title: Psychophysiology 2.3: CNS
topic: CNS terminology, spinal pathways, and core brain organization concepts.

questions.question: A bundle of axons is called a nerve in the PNS. In the CNS it is called a:

options.text: Ganglion.
Tract.
Nucleus.
Root.

questions.explanation: Equivalent terminology is nerve in PNS and tract in CNS.

questions.question: Afferent fibers are defined as fibers that:

options.text: Carry signals away from the CNS.
Carry signals toward the CNS.
Only connect cortical areas.
Only innervate smooth muscle.

questions.explanation: Afferent means signal flow toward the CNS; efferent means away.

questions.question: Which statement is correct about spinal cord function?

options.text: It only handles endocrine signaling.
It transports afferent and efferent signals between CNS and PNS.
It only controls facial expression muscles.
It replaces forebrain processing in cognition.

questions.explanation: The spinal cord is a key bidirectional pathway for sensory and motor signaling.

questions.question: Which statement best describes CNS tract?

options.text: A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.
A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.
Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.
Efferent fibers conduct signals away from the CNS.

questions.explanation: A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.

questions.question: Which statement best describes CNS nucleus?

options.text: A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.
Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.
Efferent fibers conduct signals away from the CNS.
A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.

questions.explanation: A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Afferent pathway?

options.text: A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.
Efferent fibers conduct signals away from the CNS.
Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.
A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.

questions.explanation: Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Efferent pathway?

options.text: Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.
Efferent fibers conduct signals away from the CNS.
A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.
A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.

questions.explanation: Efferent fibers conduct signals away from the CNS.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Sagittal plane?

options.text: It divides the body into left and right portions.
A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.
A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.
Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.

questions.explanation: It divides the body into left and right portions.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Coronal plane?

options.text: A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.
A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.
Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.
It divides the body into anterior and posterior portions.

questions.explanation: It divides the body into anterior and posterior portions.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Visual cortex map?

options.text: A group of neuronal cell bodies in CNS is a nucleus.
Afferent fibers conduct signals toward the CNS.
Visual cortex is organized retinotopically.
A bundle of axons in the CNS is called a tract.

questions.explanation: Visual cortex is organized retinotopically.

questions.question: Biosignals are best defined as:

options.text: Indirect estimates with no time dimension.
Directly measurable time-varying physiological parameters.
Questionnaire outcomes only.
Signals observable only after filtering.

questions.explanation: Biosignals are direct, time-varying physiological measurements.

questions.question: In unipolar recording, what is true about the reference?

options.text: Each channel must have a different reference.
Reference is only for post-processing.
All channels are measured against a shared reference.
A truly neutral site always exists on the body.

questions.explanation: Unipolar recordings use a common reference despite no perfectly neutral body site.

questions.question: If the highest frequency of interest is 100 Hz, Nyquist implies at least:

options.text: 50 Hz sampling.
100 Hz sampling.
150 Hz sampling.
200 Hz sampling.

questions.explanation: Nyquist requires at least twice the highest frequency component.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Biosignal?

options.text: A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.
Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.
All channels share a common reference electrode.
A perfectly neutral body reference site does not exist.

questions.explanation: A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Impedance?

options.text: A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.
All channels share a common reference electrode.
A perfectly neutral body reference site does not exist.
Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.

questions.explanation: Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Unipolar recording?

options.text: Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.
A perfectly neutral body reference site does not exist.
All channels share a common reference electrode.
A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.

questions.explanation: All channels share a common reference electrode.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Reference limitation?

options.text: All channels share a common reference electrode.
A perfectly neutral body reference site does not exist.
A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.
Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.

questions.explanation: A perfectly neutral body reference site does not exist.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Nyquist rule?

options.text: Sampling rate should be at least twice the highest target frequency.
A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.
Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.
All channels share a common reference electrode.

questions.explanation: Sampling rate should be at least twice the highest target frequency.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Notch filter?

options.text: A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.
Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.
All channels share a common reference electrode.
It attenuates a narrow band around one interference frequency.

questions.explanation: It attenuates a narrow band around one interference frequency.

questions.question: Which statement best describes High-pass filter?

options.text: Impedance is resistance under alternating-current conditions.
All channels share a common reference electrode.
It attenuates slower drift while preserving faster components.
A biosignal is a directly measurable time-varying physiological parameter.

questions.explanation: It attenuates slower drift while preserving faster components.

questions.question: Operationalization means:

options.text: Replacing constructs with intuition.
Defining constructs in specific measurable terms.
Removing all control variables.
Fitting a statistical model before data collection.

questions.explanation: Operationalization turns abstract constructs into measurable criteria.

questions.question: Why are within-subject designs often preferred in psychophysiology?

options.text: They remove all artifacts automatically.
Within-person variability is often lower than between-person variability.
They require no counterbalancing.
They avoid physiological recording.

questions.explanation: Lower within-person variance can improve sensitivity.

questions.question: Counterbalancing in block designs mainly helps control:

options.text: Order, learning, and fatigue effects.
Electrode impedance drift only.
Artifact rejection thresholds.
Sampling frequency errors.

questions.explanation: Counterbalancing mitigates temporal and sequence confounds.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Operationalization?

options.text: It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.
The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.
The DV is measured to reveal the effect.
It often has lower variability than between-subject designs.

questions.explanation: It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Independent variable?

options.text: It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.
The DV is measured to reveal the effect.
It often has lower variability than between-subject designs.
The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.

questions.explanation: The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Dependent variable?

options.text: The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.
It often has lower variability than between-subject designs.
The DV is measured to reveal the effect.
It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.

questions.explanation: The DV is measured to reveal the effect.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Within-subject design?

options.text: The DV is measured to reveal the effect.
It often has lower variability than between-subject designs.
It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.
The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.

questions.explanation: It often has lower variability than between-subject designs.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Counterbalancing?

options.text: It controls order, learning, and fatigue confounds.
It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.
The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.
The DV is measured to reveal the effect.

questions.explanation: It controls order, learning, and fatigue confounds.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Mediating variable?

options.text: It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.
The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.
The DV is measured to reveal the effect.
It explains mechanisms linking IV and DV.

questions.explanation: It explains mechanisms linking IV and DV.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Event-related analysis?

options.text: The IV is manipulated to induce an effect.
The DV is measured to reveal the effect.
It analyzes windows relative to specific events.
It defines constructs in specific measurable terms.

questions.explanation: It analyzes windows relative to specific events.

title: Psychophysiology 5: Electromyography
topic: EMG physiology, recording practice, and signal processing.

questions.question: A motor unit consists of:

options.text: One sensory neuron and surrounding glia.
One motor neuron, its axon, and all innervated muscle fibers.
All muscles used in a movement.
One muscle fiber and all cortical inputs.

questions.explanation: A motor unit is defined by one motor neuron and the fibers it innervates.

questions.question: Surface EMG most directly reflects:

options.text: Summed muscle fiber action potentials from active motor units.
Only cortical postsynaptic potentials.
Blood pressure changes.
EDA fluctuations.

questions.explanation: Surface EMG captures peripheral muscle electrical activity.

questions.question: A common EMG processing sequence is:

options.text: Integration -> smoothing -> rectification.
Rectification -> smoothing -> integration.
Smoothing -> integration -> rectification.
Rectification -> inversion -> downsampling.

questions.explanation: A common flow is rectify, smooth, then integrate for robust output measures.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Motor unit?

options.text: A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.
Activation follows an all-or-none principle.
Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.
EMG is often broadband with substantial power in tens-of-Hz ranges.

questions.explanation: A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Motor-unit activation?

options.text: A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.
Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.
EMG is often broadband with substantial power in tens-of-Hz ranges.
Activation follows an all-or-none principle.

questions.explanation: Activation follows an all-or-none principle.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Surface EMG origin?

options.text: Activation follows an all-or-none principle.
EMG is often broadband with substantial power in tens-of-Hz ranges.
Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.
A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.

questions.explanation: Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.

questions.question: Which statement best describes EMG spectrum?

options.text: Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.
EMG is often broadband with substantial power in tens-of-Hz ranges.
A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.
Activation follows an all-or-none principle.

questions.explanation: EMG is often broadband with substantial power in tens-of-Hz ranges.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Bipolar EMG setup?

options.text: Surface EMG is commonly recorded with bipolar placement on muscle.
A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.
Activation follows an all-or-none principle.
Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.

questions.explanation: Surface EMG is commonly recorded with bipolar placement on muscle.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Skin preparation?

options.text: A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.
Activation follows an all-or-none principle.
Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.
Mild abrasion lowers impedance and improves electrode contact.

questions.explanation: Mild abrasion lowers impedance and improves electrode contact.

questions.question: Which statement best describes EMG integration?

options.text: Activation follows an all-or-none principle.
Surface EMG reflects summed muscle-fiber action potentials.
Integration estimates total EMG output over a period.
A motor unit is one motor neuron plus its innervated fibers.

questions.explanation: Integration estimates total EMG output over a period.

title: Psychophysiology 6.1: Cardiovascular System
topic: Cardiovascular structure, cardiac conduction, and autonomic modulation.

questions.question: The cardiovascular system primarily serves to:

options.text: Store long-term memory.
Transport blood for oxygen/nutrient delivery and waste removal.
Generate EEG rhythms.
Replace endocrine communication.

questions.explanation: Its core function is transport to support tissue metabolism and homeostasis.

questions.question: Autorhythmicity means some cardiac cells can:

options.text: Depolarize spontaneously without external stimulation.
Contract only after cortical commands.
Completely ignore autonomic input.
Only activate during exercise.

questions.explanation: Pacemaker cells self-depolarize, providing intrinsic rhythm generation.

questions.question: Which statement about SA and AV nodes is correct?

options.text: AV node sets the fastest intrinsic rhythm.
SA node initiates rhythm; AV node provides a brief conduction delay.
Both nodes are mechanical valves.
Both nodes only act under parasympathetic drive.

questions.explanation: SA node usually dominates pacing; AV delay supports coordinated pumping.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Arteries?

options.text: Arteries carry blood away from the heart.
Veins carry blood toward the heart.
Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.
Pacemaker cells depolarize spontaneously without external stimulation.

questions.explanation: Arteries carry blood away from the heart.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Veins?

options.text: Arteries carry blood away from the heart.
Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.
Pacemaker cells depolarize spontaneously without external stimulation.
Veins carry blood toward the heart.

questions.explanation: Veins carry blood toward the heart.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Capillaries?

options.text: Veins carry blood toward the heart.
Pacemaker cells depolarize spontaneously without external stimulation.
Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.
Arteries carry blood away from the heart.

questions.explanation: Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Autorhythmicity?

options.text: Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.
Pacemaker cells depolarize spontaneously without external stimulation.
Arteries carry blood away from the heart.
Veins carry blood toward the heart.

questions.explanation: Pacemaker cells depolarize spontaneously without external stimulation.

questions.question: Which statement best describes SA node rhythm?

options.text: The SA node typically has higher intrinsic rhythmicity than the AV node.
Arteries carry blood away from the heart.
Veins carry blood toward the heart.
Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.

questions.explanation: The SA node typically has higher intrinsic rhythmicity than the AV node.

questions.question: Which statement best describes AV delay?

options.text: Arteries carry blood away from the heart.
Veins carry blood toward the heart.
Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.
AV delay allows atrial contraction before ventricular contraction.

questions.explanation: AV delay allows atrial contraction before ventricular contraction.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Autonomic cardiac control?

options.text: Veins carry blood toward the heart.
Capillaries are primary exchange sites for gases and nutrients.
Sympathetic input tends to speed heart rate; parasympathetic tends to slow it.
Arteries carry blood away from the heart.

questions.explanation: Sympathetic input tends to speed heart rate; parasympathetic tends to slow it.

title: Psychophysiology 6.2: Cardiovascular Measures
topic: Blood pressure, plethysmography, ECG, and HRV in psychophysiology.

questions.question: Systemic blood pressure is mainly determined by:

options.text: Cardiac output and vascular resistance.
Only vessel diameter.
Only respiratory rate.
Only endocrine activity.

questions.explanation: A core hemodynamic model combines cardiac output with vascular resistance.

questions.question: In baroreflex control, increased sensed blood pressure tends to cause:

options.text: Further increase in cardiac output.
A compensatory decrease in cardiac output.
Complete autonomic shutdown.
No response until pressure doubles.

questions.explanation: Baroreflex uses negative feedback to counter pressure increases.

questions.question: Why is HRV useful in psychophysiology?

options.text: It directly replaces blood pressure measurement.
It helps separate parasympathetic and sympathetic influences on heart dynamics.
It removes all recording artifacts.
It only indexes skeletal muscle fatigue.

questions.explanation: HRV analysis can reveal autonomic modulation patterns in cardiac timing.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Blood-pressure unit?

options.text: Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.
Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.
Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.
It enables continuous measurement of peripheral blood-volume changes.

questions.explanation: Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Baroreflex?

options.text: Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.
Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.
It enables continuous measurement of peripheral blood-volume changes.
Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.

questions.explanation: Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Cuff limitation?

options.text: Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.
It enables continuous measurement of peripheral blood-volume changes.
Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.
Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.

questions.explanation: Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Plethysmography?

options.text: Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.
It enables continuous measurement of peripheral blood-volume changes.
Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.
Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.

questions.explanation: It enables continuous measurement of peripheral blood-volume changes.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Peripheral signal caveat?

options.text: Local vascular signals may not perfectly represent whole-body state.
Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.
Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.
Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.

questions.explanation: Local vascular signals may not perfectly represent whole-body state.

questions.question: Which statement best describes ECG origin?

options.text: Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.
Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.
Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.
ECG reflects summed cardiac muscle electrical activity.

questions.explanation: ECG reflects summed cardiac muscle electrical activity.

questions.question: Which statement best describes HRV utility?

options.text: Increased sensed pressure triggers compensatory reduction in cardiac output.
Cuff-based sphygmomanometry is not ideal for continuous monitoring.
HRV spectral analysis can reflect sympathetic and parasympathetic modulation.
Blood pressure is commonly reported in mmHg.

questions.explanation: HRV spectral analysis can reflect sympathetic and parasympathetic modulation.

title: Psychophysiology 7: Electrodermal Activity
topic: Skin physiology, sweat gland activity, and EDA interpretation.

questions.question: The main physiological origin of skin conductance changes is:

options.text: Eccrine sweat gland activity.
Cortical action potentials at the scalp.
Cardiac valve motion.
Parasympathetic apocrine discharge.

questions.explanation: EDA conductance changes are primarily linked to eccrine sweat gland activity.

questions.question: Eccrine glands relevant to EDA are mainly under:

options.text: Somatic control.
Parasympathetic control.
Sympathetic control.
Enteric control.

questions.explanation: EDA is commonly interpreted as a sympathetic-linked measure.

questions.question: How are SCL and SCR typically distinguished?

options.text: SCL is phasic and SCR is tonic.
SCL is tonic/slow and SCR is phasic/event-related.
They are identical metrics with different names.
SCR exists only in ECG.

questions.explanation: SCL tracks slower baseline-like level; SCR captures transient event-related responses.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Eccrine source?

options.text: Eccrine sweat-gland activity is the main source of skin-conductance changes.
Eccrine glands relevant to EDA are under sympathetic control.
Apocrine glands secrete relatively more oily/viscous fluid.
Conductance responses are strongest in regions with dense eccrine glands.

questions.explanation: Eccrine sweat-gland activity is the main source of skin-conductance changes.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Autonomic control?

options.text: Eccrine sweat-gland activity is the main source of skin-conductance changes.
Apocrine glands secrete relatively more oily/viscous fluid.
Conductance responses are strongest in regions with dense eccrine glands.
Eccrine glands relevant to EDA are under sympathetic control.

questions.explanation: Eccrine glands relevant to EDA are under sympathetic control.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Apocrine secretion?

options.text: Eccrine glands relevant to EDA are under sympathetic control.
Conductance responses are strongest in regions with dense eccrine glands.
